titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Chiapas Media Project Records TAM.774
titlestmt.author: Rachel Mahre

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-07-19 13:26:03 -0400.

change.item: Record updated by Rachel Searcy to reflect 2021 accretion

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

physdesc.extent: in 15 manuscript boxes, 5 cassette boxes, 1 record carton, 2 flat boxes, and 1 rolled banner

did.abstract: The Chiapas Media Project Records (dated 1995-2010) consist of materials created and collected by Chiapas Media Project documenting its ongoing operations, film and video production and distribution, participation in film festivals, and engagement with indigenous communities. Materials in this collection include video recordings; correspondence with speakers, filmmakers, and festival organizers; newspaper and magazine clippings; academic research; notes and notebooks for the organization's projects; distribution and festival ephemera, including brochures, programs, posters, and catalogs; and objects, including a banner, t-shirts, and badges and press passes from festivals and conferences. The collection documents the ongoing activities of the Chiapas Media Project; the ability of indigenous and other marginalized communities to advocate for themselves through media; and topics and issues concerning indigenous human rights documented in individual works, such as agricultural collectives, indigenous land ownership claims, environmental sustainability, and the Zapatista indigenous movement.
did.langmaterial: Materials are primarily in English and Spanish. Some video recordings contain indigenous languages, including Tzeltal, Tzotzil, and Nomndaa. Some film festival catalogs and programs are in Catalan, Dutch, French Hebrew, Portuguese, Greek, and Russian.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to Box 15 is restricted until 2097.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Donated by Alexandra Halkin in August 2018 and March 2020; the accession numbers associated with this gift are 2018.134, 2021.034, and 2021.074.

appraisal.head: Appraisal
appraisal.p: During processing an archivist identified published books and personal documents. These materials were removed from the collection, deaccessioned, and offered back to the donor by a curator in 2022.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into four series, one of which is further arranged in to sub-series. The contents of each series or sub-series are arranged alphabetically. The series and sub-series arrangement of the records is as follows:
Series II: Film Festivals and Screenings;

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The Chiapas Media Project, founded in 1998 by Alexandra Halkin and Paco Vazquez, facilitated the production and distribution of media through four regional media centers built and equipped in collaboration with the Zapatista communities in Chiapas, Mexico. The Chiapas Media Project collaboratively produced 32 documentaries for international distribution, largely authored by community members themselves. The films, which focus on issues such as indigenous sovereignty, indigenous cultural practices, environmental sustainability, sustainable food practices, and autonomous education, have been screened at over 120 film festivals in 20 countries between 1998 and 2010, as well as many college and university campuses and other locations across the globe. The Chiapas Media Project is now known as Promedios de Comunicaci√≥n Comunitaria, and has been a part of the Americas Media Initiative since 2010. Promedios continues to work with indigenous and non-indigenous communities in Southern Mexico providing audiovisual training and technical support.

phystech.head: Audiovisual Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Audiovisual materials have not been preserved and may not be available to researchers. Materials not yet digitized will need to have access copies made before they can be used. To request an access copy, or if you are unsure if an item has been digitized, please contact Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, special.collections@nyu.edu, 212-998-2596 with the collection name, collection number, and a description of the item(s) requested. A staff member will respond to you with further information.

phystech.head: Born-Digital Access Policies and Procedures
phystech.p: Advance notice is required for the use of computer records. Original physical digital media is restricted.

An access terminal for born-digital materials in the collection is available by appointment for reading room viewing and listening only. Researchers may view an item's original container and/or carrier, but the physical carriers themselves are not available for use because of preservation concerns.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Chiapas Media Project Records; TAM 774; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: At the time of accessioning, audiovisual materials were separated from the archival collection for bibliographic management. The remaining collection was rehoused in archival boxes and described on the collection-level with a box-level inventory.

In July of 2022, the collection was arranged and described by an archivist. The collection was divided into Series based on record type and material was arranged intellectually within these Series. Wherever possible, record titles were taken directly from inventories or labels provided by the donor. Physically, audiovisual items are stored together with others of the same format.
One VHS tape (774_237) had a cracked cartridge, which was repaired by the Media Preservation Unit in July, 2022.

Born-digital items were identified, physically separated, and forensically imaged, analyzed, and described. New York University Libraries follow professional standards and best practices when imaging, ingesting, and processing born-digital material in order to maintain the integrity and authenticity of the content.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Chiapas Media Project, founded in 1998 by Alexandra Halkin and Paco Vazquez, facilitated the production and distribution of media through four regional media centers built and equipped in collaboration with the Zapatista communities in Chiapas, Mexico. The Chiapas Media Project collaboratively produced 32 documentaries which focus on issues such as indigenous sovereignty, indigenous cultural practices, environmental sustainability, sustainable food practices, and autonomous education. Their films and videos have been screened at over 120 film festivals in 20 countries between 1998 and 2010, as well as many college and university campuses and other locations across the globe. The Chiapas Media Project is now known as Promedios de Comunicaci√≥n Comunitaria, and has been a part of the Americas Media Initiative since 2010. Promedios continues to work with indigenous and non-indigenous communities in Southern Mexico providing audiovisual training and technical support.

The Chiapas Media Project Records (dated 1998-2010) consist of materials created and collected by the media organization documenting its ongoing operations, film and video production and distribution, participation in film festivals, and engagement with indigenous communities. Materials in this collection include video recordings; correspondence with speakers, filmmakers, and festival organizers; newspaper and magazine clippings; academic research; notes and notebooks for the organization's projects; distribution and festival ephemera, including brochures, programs, posters, and catalogs; and objects, including banners, t-shirts, name badges and press passes from festivals and conferences. The collection documents the ongoing activities of the Chiapas Media Project; the ability of indigenous and other marginalized communities to advocate for themselves through media; and topics and issues concerning indigenous human rights documented in individual works, such as agricultural collectives, indigenous land ownership claims, environmental sustainability, and the Zapatista indigenous movement.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This collection is protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use materials in the collection in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. For other uses you need to obtain permission from the rights-holder(s).

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: At the time of accessioning, some audiovisual materials were separated from the archival collection to be bibliographically cataloged and included in the Indigenous Media Collection. Those items were later reincorporated into the Chiapas Media Project Records.

physdesc.extent: in 1 record carton, 1 manuscript box, and 5 cassette boxes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This Series contains videos produced by Chiapas Media Project in collaboration with indigenous community members in Mexico and across the Americas from 1998 to 2009. The video recordings include interviews, footage of daily life, and documentaries focusing on issues such as indigenous sovereignty, labor organizing, environmental sustainability, sustainable food practices, autonomous education, resistance to military brutality, and the Zapatista movement.
In addition to the videotapes, this Series contains documentation of videotape sales, licensing contracts, and video covers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Sub-Series and video titles were taken directly from inventories supplied by the donor. Within their Sub-Series, videos are arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This Sub-Series contains work produced by Chiapas Media Project in Guerrero, Mexico.

unittitle.emph: Radio Nomanda: The Word of Water

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Radio √ëomndaa is an indigenous community radio station that began broadcasting in December 2004 in the Mexican state of Guerrero. In both √ëomndaa and Spanish, the station transmits the customs and traditions of the Nanncue √ëomndaa, rooted in respect and recognition for the region's cultural diversity.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This Sub-Series contains video interviews with indigenous filmakers in Latin America, which Alexandra Halkin conducted with funding from the Guggenheim Foundation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Living Juarez: Collateral Damage in Mexico's Drug War tells the story of the victims of Mexican President Felipe Caldaron's drug war, as well as community organizers in the Villas de Salvarcar neighborhood who protested the abuses committed by armed forces against civilians. These videotapes contain source material for the 25 minute film, which was produced in 2010, and other related videos.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This Series contains documents pertaining to the community organizing work of Chiapas Media Project, including workshops and speaking engagements, regional media centers, and youth media delegations. It also includes administrative documentation related to the Cuentos Foundation, Promedios offices in Chicago and Mexico, fundraising activities, grant applications, and budgets and expenses.

physdesc.extent: in 3 manuscript boxes and 1 flat box

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This Series contains written works by and about the Chiapas Media Project, including press clippings, research publications, academic works, internal working files.
